protocol_name: Haplotype analysis of the CDS in Arabidopsis thaliana
protocol_name_html: Haplotype analysis of the CDS in Arabidopsis thaliana
description: The simple pipeline to examine the natural variation in the coding region of your favourite gene, that you either picked by GWAS or just working on for the entire life and would like to examine what else is there to it. The pipeline described in this protocol is based on the SNP data from Arabidopsis, and so you will miss the variation due to non-Col-0 specific insertions or deletions. Nevertheless, this pipeline will give you an insight in the possible alterations of the coding region of your favourite protein
protocol_affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology

authors_list.name: Magdalena Julkowska
authors_list.affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology

status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Download the sequence of the Gene of Interest in all HapMap accessions from 1001 genomes SALK Genome Browser DB (http://signal.salk.edu/atg1001/index.php) and save them in text-editor (make sure to remove all "[", "]", and "-". Dots representing the missing data have to stay in the file as it is Alternatively – more genotypes are available from http://tools.1001genomes.org/2.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Download the sequence of the Gene of Interest in all HapMap accessions from 1001 genomes SALK Genome Browser DB (http://signal.salk.edu/atg1001/index.php) and save them in text-editor (make sure to remove all "[", "]", and "-". Dots representing the missing data have to stay in the file as it is Alternatively – more genotypes are available from http://tools.1001genomes.org/2.

components.data: Make sure that the GENE OF INTEREST is highlighted and the CDS is spelled in capital letters – this is crucial for later!
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make sure that the GENE OF INTEREST is highlighted and the CDS is spelled in capital letters – this is crucial for later!

components.data: save the file in the "Plain Text Module" as ".txt".
components.name: Description

source_data.description: save the file in the "Plain Text Module" as ".txt".

components.data: Start your terminal and type in following, to remove all the bits that are not CDS
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Start your terminal and type in following, to remove all the bits that are not CDS

components.data: Change your directory to where you have your .txt files stored by typing - "cd /Users/julkowmm/Desktop/Haplotype"
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Change your directory to where you have your .txt files stored by typing - "cd /Users/julkowmm/Desktop/Haplotype"

components.data: Remove all the "small" letters representing non-CDS sequences by typing - "cat AT5G66270_Zink_finger_CDS.txt | perl -e '$count=1; foreach $line (<STDIN>) {if ($count==1) {print $line; $count=$count+1;} elsif ($line=~/>/) {print "\n$line";} else {chomp $line; print $line; }}' | sed -e 's/^.*rev//g' | sed '/^>/! s/[atgc]//g' | sed -e 's/\.//g'> AT5G66270_Zink_finger_protein.txt ". Make sure to replace "AT5H66270_Zink_finger_CDS.txt" and "AT5G66270_Zink_finger_protein.txt" by the name of your input and output file respectively
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove all the "small" letters representing non-CDS sequences by typing - "cat AT5G66270_Zink_finger_CDS.txt | perl -e '$count=1; foreach $line (<STDIN>) {if ($count==1) {print $line; $count=$count+1;} elsif ($line=~/>/) {print "\n$line";} else {chomp $line; print $line; }}' | sed -e 's/^.*rev//g' | sed '/^>/! s/[atgc]//g' | sed -e 's/\.//g'> AT5G66270_Zink_finger_protein.txt ". Make sure to replace "AT5H66270_Zink_finger_CDS.txt" and "AT5G66270_Zink_finger_protein.txt" by the name of your input and output file respectively

components.data: Put the sequences in FAbox for collapsing them into individual haplotypes Go to:  http://users-birc.au.dk/biopv/php/fabox/click on "DNA to haplotype collapser and converter" insert your sequences in the window and collapse the sequences
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Put the sequences in FAbox for collapsing them into individual haplotypes Go to:  http://users-birc.au.dk/biopv/php/fabox/click on "DNA to haplotype collapser and converter" insert your sequences in the window and collapse the sequences

components.data: Download the individual Haplotype sequences as well as the file where you have which accessions are represented by which phenotype.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Download the individual Haplotype sequences as well as the file where you have which accessions are represented by which phenotype.

components.data: Translate the haplotype sequences into protein using JalView - to download JalView - http://www.jalview.org/
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Translate the haplotype sequences into protein using JalView - to download JalView - http://www.jalview.org/

components.data: Sort the aligned sequences by pairwise comparisons – eliminate Haplotypes which are exactly the same on protein level
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Sort the aligned sequences by pairwise comparisons – eliminate Haplotypes which are exactly the same on protein level

components.data: Remove redundant haplotypes from the input file and start from #10 IMPORTANT: make sure that you note which haplotypes were collapsed together – otherwise you will end up with quite a big mess
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove redundant haplotypes from the input file and start from #10 IMPORTANT: make sure that you note which haplotypes were collapsed together – otherwise you will end up with quite a big mess

components.data: Match the accessions with the specific haplotype groups as identified with FaBox collapser, and replace the haplotypes that could be further collapsed into one group based on the amino acid sequence
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Match the accessions with the specific haplotype groups as identified with FaBox collapser, and replace the haplotypes that could be further collapsed into one group based on the amino acid sequence

components.data: Match the accessions and the haplotype grouping with the phenotypes
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Match the accessions and the haplotype grouping with the phenotypes

components.data: Examine the significant differences between your haplotype groups. ADVICE: use only haplogroups that consist of 3 or more genotypes. Otherwise the haplotype data analysis is not very reliable.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Examine the significant differences between your haplotype groups. ADVICE: use only haplogroups that consist of 3 or more genotypes. Otherwise the haplotype data analysis is not very reliable.

components.data: Select the haplotypes that are giving you the most interesting / significant differences in your phenotype data and isolate the amino acid sequences of those specific haplotypes in a separate ".txt" file
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Select the haplotypes that are giving you the most interesting / significant differences in your phenotype data and isolate the amino acid sequences of those specific haplotypes in a separate ".txt" file

components.data: Import the ".txt" file with the most interesting haplotypes into Jalview and color the amino acids by ClustalX in JalView
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Import the ".txt" file with the most interesting haplotypes into Jalview and color the amino acids by ClustalX in JalView

components.data: Format the final alignment by wrapping the text, adding scale above, below and right, boxes, txt, show gaps. The alignment should be 125 amino acids long (otherwise not readable at print-out) and saved in the PDF format.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Format the final alignment by wrapping the text, adding scale above, below and right, boxes, txt, show gaps. The alignment should be 125 amino acids long (otherwise not readable at print-out) and saved in the PDF format.

components.data: Check the location of the known protein domains with Uniprot - http://www.uniprot.org/ - and mark the identified domains in the PDF. Check whether different haplotypes have altered sequence in identified protein domains to further build up your hypothesis.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Check the location of the known protein domains with Uniprot - http://www.uniprot.org/ - and mark the identified domains in the PDF. Check whether different haplotypes have altered sequence in identified protein domains to further build up your hypothesis.

components.data: Pick the most interesting haplotypes for cloning and allele complementation, based on the differences observed in the phenotypes between different "haplogroups", as well as protein sequence.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pick the most interesting haplotypes for cloning and allele complementation, based on the differences observed in the phenotypes between different "haplogroups", as well as protein sequence.
